												Lovers in a Dangerous Spacetime is a space style action shooter with heavy co-op elements. The game was released on Steam and Xbox One in September 2015 by indie developer Asteroid Base.Whilst the game is focuses on the co-op element, the game can be played alone. You are in command of a space ship with a companion, in the single player this is a partly UI controlled pet, dog or cat, when playing co-op, the other player controls this character. The space ship has various seats that must be commanded in order for that part of the ship to be active, the seats consist of outer canons,  rotating gun, shields, maps and boosters; so that means only two parts of the ship can be active at one time. When playing single player, the UI controlled companion makes for a perfect rider of the ships weaponry as they can shoot targets even when you can't actually see them on the screen. I was quite happy to man the direction of the ship for the majority of the play through and just used the companion to switch between the more skill targeted seats. The actual aim in the game is to collect kidnapped space bunnies - these are spread out across the levels and some are not easy to find due to a fog of war feature also being included.  Whilst exploring and destroying other enemies, you will collect upgrades for your ships; these upgrades can be used on any of the ship's compartments, such as turning your canons into rail guns, or upgrading your ships boosters to go even faster.Lovers in a Dangerous Spacetime has a really neat graphic style - the neon art really shines through and actually fits in well with the gameplay. The bosses in this game look awesome; they look like something a child would drawer but have a real mature look about them. There isn't any voice acting though which I thought is a real shame given that there is a fair amount of text to be read. The soundtrack is stellar, and all of the sound effects are nice too. There are two levels of difficulties, easy and medium. I actually found the medium level to be really intensive, and actually had to drop the difficulty down on some of the levels - it's nice to see a game have challenging gameplay. This game takes a huge amount of skill to master it properly.  Every level in Lovers in a Dangerous Spacetime is randomly generated; meaning no play through is ever the same. There are four chapters, and each chapter consists of four levels with a boss fight at the end. All of the regular levels have the same aim as noted above, collecting the space bunnies/frogs/ducks and foxes.I finished the game in just under four hours; so it is fairly short, but it has the added bonus of having the local multiplayer option which is absolutely huge - this ramps the replay ability up tenfold for me, given that all of the maps are randomly generated, you can play this game for hours on end with a buddy on the couch.  Technically, this is a sound game; I was able to play on 4K resolutions, with in game options too.  A controller is recommended to play though; whilst keyboard and mouse is viable, you will definitely get more out of using a controller as the analogue stick makes a big difference when controlling the ship. The game does offer a fairly expansive tutorial too; and this gets you to grips with the controls very easily as it guides you through everything step by step. In conclusion; Lovers in a Dangerous Spacetime is a top notch title; a really fantastic art style and with an innovative take on the co-op controls of a ship, this is special game. If you only plan on playing this game on your own, you may find the price tag of £10,99 to be a little much, but if you are going to be playing it on co-op with friends, then you are going to get more than your money’s worth out of this game. This is certainly a game to keep installed even after completing it! 												LiaDS is a very cool game. You are on a mission to restore love to the galaxy in your spaceship, with either one player and an AI helper, or local co-op. It has a pretty unique gimmick, in that you must move your characters from station to station in order to control parts of the ship you're flying. What this means in practice is that most of the time one person will be flying the ship, while the other moves between the guns and the shields defending you. In special circumstances both players will have to man the defenses while the ship idles.The graphics are super cutesy, and they belie the absolutely punishing difficulty of this game. You'll need a competent second player to match the excellent performance of your AI pet, who zips between stations at your command and just kicks butt on the regular. But when things are in a groove and the chaos is all around you, the game is incredibly satisfying. And the good number of power-up combinations keeps things interesting. Just be prepared for the occasional frustration as the hordes of attackers wipe you out yet again.The unique mechanic of only being able to control one station at a time makes this game feel like a mix between FTL: Faster Than Light and a shoot-em-up. It's honestly inspiring to see such an innovative gameplay concept these days, when it sometimes feels like all the genres possible have been conceived already. Which is to say, I can see this as the foundation of a new genre, much like Minecraft single-handedly brough the crafting genre into existence. It's that good. I found it intriguing enough that I bought it at only a small discount, which is incredibly rare for me.EDIT: Having played this game a few more hours, my estimation of it continues to increase. Rather than getting stale, it's becoming more entertaining the deeper I go. The power up combinations hold some amazing surprises, the music is fantastic, and the game is so well put together and so polished, it's like the distilled essence of joy to play it. I'm willing to call it the best game of the year right now.

												Lovers in Dangerous Spacetime:~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~  The power of the Ardor Reactor brings stability and happiness to the galaxy. Love is the flavour of everyday…. Interplanetary peace and love, should we say! Unfortunately, an error in the matrix (in the Ardor Reactor) has damaged the reactor. An explosion occurred and as a result it split in four pieces. But this is the least of your predicaments; the fault allowed the dark forces of Anti-Love to breakout and spread through the galaxy. Your goal is to recover the four pieces of the reactor to save the galaxy.  Lovers in Dangerous Spacetime is a local co-op game setup in a space environment.  You and your AI companion (or a friend in local co-op) will be in command of a circular spaceship prototype to save the galaxy. The vessel has eight stations, four guns (north, south, east and west), one shield, one scanner, one super weapon and one engine station. All can be upgraded by collecting gems and you could end up with an interesting combination of weapons, from lasers to missiles or even a giant flail - how cool is that? You will have several missions per sector and will have to save a minimum of five folks (bunnies or frogs) to unlock the escape portal to finish your assignment. You will face a good mixture of enemies (including bosses) in well-designed levels. Also, every time you start a new campaign, levels will randomly generate themselves which adds so much in terms of replay ability. I would strongly recommend using a gamepad for this game as the keyboard setup is actually not the way to go. 												Lovers is a fantastic (local-only) coop experience and maybe my favorite couples game on steam. The gameplay is solid, the art is splendid, and the story is enjoyable fluff. More importantly, you'll both be having fun. Single-player is fine enough, but it will feel a little lacking if you've played with someone else. That's not really a fault of the game, as the AI partner performs well (and better than anyone I played with). It's just not as compelling as having a human to work with (and around), someone who isn't there just to obey your whims.

			Genna plays Lovers in a Dangerous Spacetime. A game where you and a real or AI friend pilot a ship, while running to different weapons to fend off enemies.		

The game shares a few similarities to FTL or Guns of Icarus, in the sense that you need to navigate from different parts of your ship in order to survive. Although, because you're only 2 crew members, it's much more intense.In singleplayer, you can tell your AI pet what to take control of. In co-op, anyone can take control of anything. It's in 2 player mode that the game shines, in my opinion.Your main objective is to free the set amount of bunnies in each level. Once you've done that, the level exit will open. If you choose to stay and uncover the entire map, look for all possible upgrades and free all bunnies, then each level can take you between 15-30 minutes. On top of that, each time you start a new campaign, levels will be randomly generated, adding infinite replay value.The game becomes incredibly satisfying as you upgrade your ship. Different gems can be used to modify different parts of the ship. For example. putting a pink gem on you turret will make it a triple barreled machine gun. Putting a blue gem will turn it into a yo-yo like wrecking ball. Putting a pink gem on you shield will make it cover more of your ship. Putting a yellow gem will make it smaller, but deflect projectiles. You can even combine gems to create different powerups. As you rank up. you can also unlock different ships that have different attributes. It makes the game so much fun.The art style is incredibly cute, and the music is cool.Overall, I think this game is awesome! Give it a try

												If like me, you've always wanted a game where you and a few friends are the crew of a starship on a harrowing adventure, then this just might be the game for you. In a nutshell, Lovers is a space action game where 1-4 players share the task of running a small spaceship. Your tiny characters run and jump from room to room to man weapon turrets, direct shields, activate special weapons and pilot your space jalopy. If you've played FTL, that will give you a rough idea of how the ship is layed out. As you thrust around the 2D enviorments dodging space rocks and blasting a menagerie of baddies your main goal is to rescue imprisoned space bunnies who annoyingly scream when you get near them. Once you've located and freed enough of them the exit will open and you can blast your way to the next level. It's a simple formula that stays fresh for a few reasons: Firstly, each module on your ship can be augmented with a gem that changes it's function. For instance a metal gem, turns your gun turret into a tethered spike ball that you launch at enemies and retract. A beam gem placed in your shield generator allows you to deflect enemy projectiles back at them, etc. With upgrades you can add 2 gems to each module for even more varied abilities. Secondly, the enviorments in each level provide just enough in new obstacles to keep from getting stale. A water level might have a rushing current that carries you around a level while sinister pods sticking to the walls will burst unleashing a group of small enemies upon you if you get to close. Lastly, the games core gameplay co-op spaceship action, is simple, fun, frantic and challenging enough that it will keep you and your friends engaged for a long time.On the minus side, playing with 3-4 people is the ideal number and any less can become frustrating as you will constantly need to run all over your ship. With only 1 or 2 people this means one of your important ship systems will be unmanned, leaving you vulnerable in one way or another in dire situations. For instance, there are several cases where enemies will frantically swarm you and the best course of action is to jet away while your buddies shield to fend them off and blast a trail for you with a weapon turret. With out the manpower to cover all your systems it can be very difficult to survive in these situations. In single player you are given a competent AI partner and you have the option of lowering the difficulty, but the problem still persists. And to compound this problem is the glaring omission of online play. While playing Lovers with a room of friends is a great experience that we don't get enough of these days, the convenience of online play should not have been ignored and would still provide a great co-op experience.Despite these issues. Lovers manages to provide a unique, charming and visually striking space adventure like no other. As a single player experience it's still an enjoyable game. However, if you have the means to play with 3-4 people, this is when Lovers really shines.8.5/10

You get the same opponents and similar obstacles but the layout changes. It's not the level of some other games but enough to keep the levels from becoming a chore to repeat if you fail.Each campaing has a different theme and ends in a pretty cool and challenging boss fight. 												Summary: A TRUE co-operative experience that's rarely seen. Like another great example, "Overcooked", this game has perfectly captured the essence of co-operative play, and player co-ordination through strong communication. Unlike most "co-op" games, trying to go it alone, or trying to "be the best guy" doesn't fly here. You'll work together, running around a ship, controlling turrets, shields, lasers, and guiding the ship through hazardous space. It's a LOT of fun, and I would say a must buy for local couch co-op. Pros:+ Designed around co-operative play+ Co-op Campaign+ The "lone wolf" mentality is rightly the worst choice, as should be the case in a good co-op experience (see Overcooked as another great example of this)+ Quick to learn+ Encourages participation from gamers of a variety of skill levels+ Encourages strong communication between players+ The screen is tidy, and everything sized just right to lend to visual clarity+ Up to 4 players can play at once+ Couch co-op, Steam link works great, and has great controller supportCons:- Not much... the players who like to be "winning" will be sadly disappointed, but that makes me VERY happy- Online co-op not supported (I prefer couch co-op, but I ca see this being a drawback for some)

												An absolute joy to play! LiaDS is a fantasticly intuitive and engaging take on the "Local Multiplayer," game genre. So much, that the game is infinitely more rewarding with more friends to play. By that token, buys beware: it is highly recommended you bring additional passengers for this ride!Great presentation and audio make this an endearing package, with gameplay that is simple to understand, but hard to master as the levels progress. It is evident that an enormous amount of effort was invested into LiaDS, a sediment which is echoed by excellent aethestics, difficulty progression, and engaging gameplay.A few gripes do not escape this game from a hearty recommendation. Gamers who are wishing for a forgiving game will be marginally dissapointed, as after a couple hours of gameplay, the level of challenge ramps up significantly. Game levels become long, and trecherous. A misfired cannon, or an unmanned engine can potentionally lead to demise; a loss of 20-30 minutes of gameplay to restart the level.By inverse, the game is rewarding. If you can progress in the game with enough skill and determination, you are rewarded with more gadgets and enemys to test the might of your friends and yourself. If you are interested in a well-constructed, engaging, and fun local multiplayer game, look no further. Lovers in a Dangerous Spacetime is a voyage your friends will be begging you to embark on again, and again!

												This game is a gem !Very cute, very fun and litteraly a wonder to play with friends !It's simple, easy to learn and the harder difficulty levels offer quite a challenge.You can upgrade your ship as you wish, using various combination and powerups and unlocking different ships layouts.Each level I've seen so far were different from one another, with their own particular settings and challenges.The game succeed in giving you the feeling that you're on a journey through various distant bits of space.Playing with friends is incredible ! Co-op is where this game really shines. It's good to mention that you and your friend(s) get to play side by side, using controllers or the same keyboard. Attempting to work as an efficient team, running between the various stations of the ship to counter every challenges with good timing, trying to synergize as best as you can with your friends, it feels great, especialy when you beat some tough boss or especialy difficult level.The different types of stations you can control requires different skills and offer different challenges. As a team you get to learn how to use everyone's skills in the most efficient way. As an exemple : I might not be good with turrets, I can still pilot the ship very well or use the shields to intercept as many projectiles as possible, making the ship much more resilient while my friends gun down everything. This make co-op interesting even with friends who are not aquainted with the game, as some stations are easier than others.Even if you don't play with friends, the game is still very fun. You can choose a lovely AI pet that you can order to switch stations at will. You'll end up being the pilot since it's almost the only thing the AI won't do, yet it will be a different challenge than co-op since you'll have to manage your pet between the turrets, shield and map while attempting to navigate through various threats.It's one of these rare games with a fun/price ratio where the amount of fun outweights the price by far !

												The team at Asteroid Base Inc. have absolutley outdone themselves. Just one look at the screen is all it takes to recognize ABI's articulate attention to detail. The heart melting & cutesy visual style of this game coupled with LiaDS's intense co-op experience keeps me coming back for more. At first glance this game may seem as though it could be short, however, the ever changing game dynamics you encounter within each solar system keeps the game fresh and challenging. Not only will the player encounter new obsticles and enemies, but the biomes in each universe provide new reasons to rethink your tacitcs, loadouts (power-ups), or even the ship you wish to spread the love with. Including the tutorial, there are 5 systems to venture through that each hold several levels, which once again may leave you with a feeling that there isn't enough. Though I'll challenge that notion by asserting that each level can take anywhere from 15 minutes to a half an hour or more. Having said that, the game also provides a challenging normal difficulty that leaves room for the players to improve upon their tactics and teamwork. I'm excited to feel the love on hard mode ._. 10 out of motherloving 10.

Great couch co-op, swinging spiked laser-balls at aliens has never been so fun!This hit on a really good recipe of platform/shmup starship crewing, which could be even better if developers find time to add network play.LOVERS is a true co-operative experience because you need your teammates taking care of different roles in order to succeed.Playing with only two people is difficult as you must pick any two out of shooting/moving/deflecting projectiles at one time, which I guess adds a sort of challenge in prioritising and communicating, but in some situations that takes a huge toll on your survivability compared to if you have 3 or more players.This seems to have great controller support too; I have been able to set up 4 players using even the complex combination of one Xbox360 controller, two PS2 dualshock 2 controllers plugged into a dual adapter, and one player on keyboard, and it works fine. That was testing on Linux though so YMMV.For best results you should plug them in before starting, then assign controllers to players through the options menu.The only negative thing I can say about it after a few hours of playtime is that you can't skip a quite lengthy intro cutscene when starting a new profile, which I found quite annoying, so please fix this.I've only played DRM-free so far since getting it from the Humble store, hence the playtime, but just tested it on Steam and found that it detects existing save files from the same directory, which is also good.N.B. the spiked laser balls are not balls made of lasers, but rather spikey flailing metal balls that shoot lasers out of them!
